message_1: A sample of radioactive isotope of carbon-14 has an initial activity of 10,000 decays per second. If the half-life of carbon-14 is 5,700 years, what will be its activity after 17,100 years?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the radioactive decay formula:

Activity_final = Activity_initial * (1/2)^(time_elapsed / half_life)

where Activity_final is the activity of the sample after 17,100 years, Activity_initial is the initial activity (10,000 decays per second), time_elapsed is the time that has passed (17,100 years), and half_life is the half-life of carbon-14 (5,700 years).

Activity_final = 10,000 * (1/2)^(17,100 / 5,700)

First, we need to find the number of half-lives that have passed:

17,100 / 5,700 = 3

Now, we can plug this value back into the formula:

Activity_final = 10,000 * (1/2)^3

Activity_final = 10,000 * (1/8)

Activity_final = 1,250 decays per second

So, after 17,100 years, the activity of the carbon-14 sample will be 1,250 decays per second.
